name: local ring of $\Spec \mathcal{C}^\infty(\RR)$ at zero

proofs.irreducible: Let $f(x) = g(-x) = 0$ for $x \le 0$ and $f(x) = g(-x) = e^{-1/x^2}$ for $x > 0$. Then $fg \in I$ while $f, g \not\in I$.
proofs.locally-noetherian: Let $I_\varepsilon = \{ f \in R \mid f(x) = 0 \textup{ for all } |x| < \varepsilon \}$. Then $I_1 \subsetneq I_{\frac{1}{2}} \subsetneq I_{\frac{1}{3}} \subsetneq \cdots \subset I$, so $R/I$ is not noetherian.
proofs.reduced: If $f^n \in I$ for some $f \in \mathcal{C}^\infty(\RR)$, then there exists some $\varepsilon > 0$ such that $f^n(x) = 0$ for all $|x| < \varepsilon$, but then also $f(x) = 0$ for all $|x| < \varepsilon$, so $f \in I$.

description: The scheme $\Spec S$, where $S = R_\mathfrak{m} = R/I$ with $R = \mathcal{C}^\infty(\RR)$ and $\mathfrak{m} = \{ f \in R \mid f(0) = 0 \}$ and $I = \{ f \in R \mid \exists \varepsilon > 0 \textup{ s.t. } f(x) = 0 \textup{ for all } |x| < \varepsilon \}$. See Stacks 052H$.
